node.text:
Lexie and 5-year-old Logan had to take matters into their own hands today. Here’s the truth: When 90% of female characters in popular animated shows fit the exact same mold (super thin + curves, huge eyes, tiny nose and chin, and plump lips), it cements beauty ideals in girls’ minds that last a lifetime. Even as the storylines become more progressive and inclusive, the images of female characters are not catching up. At best, this shows a major lack of creativity from creators. At worst, it shows their sexist, objectifying view of girls and women. Do not let this go unnoticed in your house. We can help, too. We equip you with the resources to talk to and teach your kids (and yourselves) about this crucial ability to be media literate in our book, More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. (Linked in bio). 
➕Tell us and those seeing this post what shows feature their characters in more equitable, representative, empowering ways in the comments! We’ll add the ones we are digging, too! 
➕Logan’s wall in the background also features designs from a billboard campaign we did 10 YEARS ago that say, “You are capable of much more than being looked at” and “If beauty hurts, we’re doing it wrong.” My how time flies!🥰#morethanabody

node.title: Helping kids see more + be more

node.text:
What surprised us the most in our doctoral body image research? Lindsay shares the interesting difference between women who feel good about their bodies because they look good vs. those who hated their bodies because they look "bad" -- and what they all had in common regardless of how they looked. Watch or listen til the end for the good stuff! 
👙Hint: being thin, having a perfect "bikini body," looking young while aging, and meeting every other female beauty ideal isn't the cure-all confidence solution you might think it is. 🙏🏼Thankfully, we found MUCH more effective, achievable and sustainable answers for your body image woes!
📖Find our book, More Than a Body, by Lindsay and Lexie Kite, PhD, everywhere books are sold (hardcover, ebook, audio!) or at your library -- shopping links in our bio!

node.title: Loving Your Looks Won't Fix Things

node.text:
Our game-changing TEDx talk took place 4 years ago, and it still holds up! (Phew). Linds nails the core of our work at Beauty Redefined and our debut book, More Than a Body, in these few minutes. 
✖️As she says here and we fully dive into in our book, "Girls and women aren't only suffering because of the unattainable ways beauty is being defined, they're suffering because THEY ARE BEING DEFINED BY BEAUTY. They are bodies first and people second. So rather than working to make sure more women's bodies are viewed as valuable, we are focused on making sure women are valued as more than bodies to view."🔥💥🙌🏽
✖️The truth is: Feeling like other people think you look good is fleeting, and it's causing you to put your power in the hands of onlookers. It's shoving you onto an exhausting roller coaster of ups and downs based on validation from others and good lighting and bad hair days and on and on. You are more than a body. You are not required to please the eyes of those who see you. You have work to do, and we need you out here! We need YOU -- not a pretty vision of you -- all of you.
➕If you feel the power of her words here, you’ll dig our book, “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. Complete with our personal stories of growing up as identical twins that were constantly compared (including 13-yr-old journal entries), finding purpose in our lifetimes of body shame when we went to college and realized we could help people heal from their shame, and putting ALL our research and answers to help people rise with body image resilience into our book is the best and hardest thing we’ve ever done. Like harder than writing doctoral dissertations, giving birth, and trying not to laugh when people asked us growing up, “How do you know if you are Lexie or Lindsay when you wake up in the morning?”😂 The full TEDx talk is linked in our bio, or just search Lindsay Kite TEDx on YouTube! 📚 Get “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD (available in our OWN twin voices as an audiobook, too!) wherever books are sold (linked in bio & morethanabody.org). #morethanabody #seemorebemore

node.text:
Your body has probably changed this past year inside -- maybe in ways you don't love. Don't let that hold you back or delay "getting back out there," whether dating, vacationing, seeing friends and family, going back to your office, and anything else you're self-objectifying your way out of. It's time to test some anxious body image boundaries to build your resilience and have FUN in the process.
👏🏼💗📢 Here is a lil pep talk and a couple things to keep in mind as you venture out! If this resonates, our book will too -- "More Than a Body" by me (Lindsay Kite, PhD and my sis, Lexie) is available in hardcover (40% off on Amazon via link in bio!), ebook, and audio everywhere. #morethanabody

node.title: Get Back Out There! (A Pep Talk)

node.text:
Let's talk about anger. This video from me (Lexie Kite, PhD) and this excerpt from our book, More Than a Body, (p.321) are the sermon you might need to hear right now:
📖"When you see the heavy costs and the toll this objectifying culture takes on you and your loved ones physically, mentally, and spiritually, deep, painful emotions are understandable and expected. You might know that your body is an instrument, while the outside world — even people and institutions you love and rely on — continues to see you as an ornament.
🔥Being objectified should be infuriating, and your fury will protect you from accepting and internalizing it. Your anger might not feel comfortable, and it might feel really out of place for the many women who have learned to suppress those feelings in favor of more subdued, pleasant, and self-sacrificing options. But rage and sadness aren’t a bad or wrong way to feel about a cultural system that has inflicted real damage on so many of us, putting us at odds with our own bodies and sinking us into shame. Let those painful emotions fuel your fire to make progress and push for change — in your own life and for others.
➕Anger, sadness, and regret might be the signal that you are undergoing a revolutionary, enabling disruption that is propelling you toward a new, more fulfilling way of living. The objectification you experience in your life can motivate you and remind you to be more of who you are and who you could be. Not doubled, disembodied, and divided, but whole, embodied, and complete." 
📚More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD is available in English worldwide in hardcover, audiobook, and Kindle (and still 40% off on Amazon!). Linked in bio or at morethanabody.org. If you share about the book on social media, we’ll send you our “instrument not ornaments” and “more than a body” vinyl decals! Info linked in bio. #morethanabody

node.text:
Today is the one-month anniversary of our book, More Than a Body! We have been honored and thrilled to see you guys reading it and sharing it and picking it for your book clubs!😍We cannot thank you enough. Your words and about how this book has changed you mean more to us than any IG caption can convey. For those of you who didn’t join us for our book launch event, here is a clip of Lexie reading an excerpt from the book that has really resonated with people. We hope you feel it, and love the book! 
👊🏽More Than a Body is available in hardcover📚, audiobook🎧, and Kindle📱wherever you buy books! #morethanabody #seemorebemore

node.title: Book Reading: More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD

node.text:
Lindsay’s game-changing TEDx talk took place 3 years ago, and it still holds up! (But don’t read the YouTube comments, for your own well-being. It’ll counteract all the good of hearing this talk!) She nails the core of our work at Beauty Redefined in these few minutes.
✖️As Linds says here and we fully dive into in our book, "Girls and women aren't only suffering because of the unattainable ways beauty is being defined, they're suffering because THEY ARE BEING DEFINED BY BEAUTY. They are bodies first and people second. So rather than working to make sure more women's bodies are viewed as valuable, we are focused on making sure women are valued as more than bodies to view."🔥💥🙌🏽
✖️The truth is: Feeling like other people think you look good is fleeting, and it's causing you to put your power in the hands of onlookers. It's shoving you onto an exhausting roller coaster of ups and downs based on validation from others 👍🏼and good lighting💁🏽‍♀️ and bad hair days 🤦🏼‍♀️and on and on. You are more than a body. You are not required to please the eyes of those who see you. You have work to do, and we need you out here! We need YOU -- not a pretty vision of you -- all of you.
✖️If you feel the power of her words here, you’ll dig our new book, “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. Complete with our personal stories of growing up as identical twins that were constantly compared (including 13-yr-old journal entries), finding purpose in our lifetimes of body shame when we went to college and realized we could help people heal from their shame, and putting ALL our research and answers to help people rise with body image resilience into our book is the best and hardest thing we’ve ever done. Like harder than writing doctoral dissertations, giving birth, and trying not to laugh when people asked us growing up, “How do you know if you are Lexie or Lindsay when you wake up in the morning?”😂 The full TEDx talk is linked in our bio, or just search Lindsay Kite TEDx on YouTube! 📚 And pre-order our book, “More Than a Body” (available in our OWN twin voices as an audiobook, too!) wherever books are sold (& morethanabody.org). #morethanabody #seemorebemore

node.text:
We could talk about the complicated topic of modesty, dress codes, and sexualization of girls all day long, but instead here’s Lindsay talking for just a couple mins to summarize our perspective! 
✖️You’re probably thinking, “But how do we implement appropriate dress codes for certain situations like schools? What does this look like in practice?” and while we’ve written about this a bit elsewhere, our full solution is in our book, “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD, which hits mailboxes and shelves next month!🙌🏽🥳🙌🏽 You can order it anywhere you buy books, and we highly recommend giving it as a holiday gift to all those who need a deep and motivational pep talk about who they are and why they are so much more than the lies they’ve been sold! Link in bio or at morethanabody.org.
#morethanabody #morethanabodybook #seemorebemore

node.title: Stop sexualizing girls with typical modesty talk

node.text:
Believe it or not, one of the things we love most in the world is doing speaking events and live Q and A’s! Though we’ve had to move all of our events promoting our new book to virtual, there are some perks! Like getting more people access to our message than those that can be in the room, and only having to get fancy from the waist up! 😅Following our recent book talk at the University of Utah (which we did from the comfort of our homes in NYC and SLC!), we answered some of your questions live. Here’s Lexie’s answer to the pressing and popular question, “How do I help my daughter see herself as more than a body when I have a hard time doing it myself?!” 
✖️You know we could talk about this all day, so we put it ALL in our book, “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD, which hits mailboxes and shelves next month!🙌🏽🥳🙌🏽 You can order it anywhere you buy books, and we highly recommend giving it as a holiday gift to all those who need a deep and motivational pep talk about who they are and why they are so much more than the lies they’ve been sold! Link in bio. 
#morethanabody #morethanabodybook #seemorebemore

node.title: How do I help my daughter’s body image when I am struggling?

node.text: Did you miss our first IG LIVE? We've got your back! Join Lexie and Lindsay Kite, PhDs and co-directors of Beauty Redefined, as we guide you through some therapeutic techniques and strategies to fight off body shame and reconnect with yourself like you did when you were young, before you were self-conscious of your body. (😂And please forgive us for the shoddy screen recording! The whole video wouldn’t save so we had to screen record and I may have received some texts during it). ✖️When we were young, we all knew we were more than bodies to be looked at, judged, and fixed. But at a very young age, each of us forgot that truth. We started to feel defined by and very aware of the look of our bodies, and it impacts our health, happiness, feelings of self-worth and confidence, and beyond. We get really personal in this video and hope you'll dig deep to heal, too. We'll also share some tips on how to care for little girls in ways that will help them learn they are more than bodies to be looked at. ✖️If you want more of this inspiration and research-driven strategies for body image resilience, enroll in our online body image course at the link in bio or at beautyredefined.org #morethanabody #seemorebemore #beautyredefined

node.title: Dealing with Body Shame & Boosting Your Body Image in ISOLATION

node.text:
Allow ourselves to reintroduce ourselves! We are Lindsay & Lexie Kite, co-directors of the nonprofit Beauty Redefined and co-authors of the book More Than a Body! As we do every six months, we’ll tell you a bit about us and you do the same in the comments! Swipe for pics (which witch is which?)
•Lindsay is living her dream in NYC (though the pandemic complicated that a bit, forcing us to share a space for the first time since we were 19!😬 And we fought hard but also finished writing our book sharing a tiny space so it’s aallll good.
•Lexie lives in Salt Lake City, with her husband (whom she met on her first blind date ever😍) and their two daughters, Logan (5, see yesterday’s video post for her genius dog cloud☁️ ) and Lane (1). She’s really living her best life.
•Lindsay is single and pleasantly surprised by the NY dating scene. She entertains all her friends and fam with endless dating stories (great and terrrrrible). 
•We have a shared disdain for all meat except chicken without bones in it, white condiments (& cottage cheese), movies that feature cartoons mixed w/ real people, and people who say, “can I play devil’s advocate for minute?”
•We are both Real Housewife superfans (RHONY was great until this season, RHOP brings the HEAT, and we are eagerly anticipating season 2 of RHOSLC).
•We grew up being competitive swimmers, spellers, and, well, sisters. We competed over every single thing to see which twin was better, smarter, faster, cooler, etc. forever. V v exhausting. Do not recommend. 
•We graduated with PhDs in body image & media studies together in 2013 & have both worked in nonprofit development (fundraising) in addition to running @beauty_redefined — a skill set we picked up during grad school fellowships at the @universityofutah. 
•Our book has been out in the world for 6 months and it is the most exciting opportunity we’ve EVERRR HAD and the fact that you guys are buying it, borrowing it, listening to it on the audiobook we narrated OURSELVES, posting about it and sharing it is the thrill of a lifetime. We are beyond honored by your response to it and wish we could hug and thank each of you.🥰 Now tell us about YOU!👇🏼#morethanabody

node.text:
Lexie and 5-year-old Logan had to take matters into their own hands today. Here’s the truth: When 90% of female characters in popular animated shows fit the exact same mold (super thin + curves, huge eyes, tiny nose and chin, and plump lips), it cements beauty ideals in girls’ minds that last a lifetime. Even as the storylines become more progressive and inclusive, the images of female characters are not catching up. At best, this shows a major lack of creativity from creators. At worst, it shows their sexist, objectifying view of girls and women. Do not let this go unnoticed in your house. We can help, too. We equip you with the resources to talk to and teach your kids (and yourselves) about this crucial ability to be media literate in our book, More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. (Linked in bio). 
➕Tell us and those seeing this post what shows feature their characters in more equitable, representative, empowering ways in the comments! We’ll add the ones we are digging, too! 
➕Logan’s wall in the background also features designs from a billboard campaign we did 10 YEARS ago that say, “You are capable of much more than being looked at” and “If beauty hurts, we’re doing it wrong.” My how time flies!🥰#morethanabody

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'A women's handball team is boycotting mandated bikini bottoms for being sexist and inhibiting while the men's teams are fully clothed. This type of uniform double standard is everywhere and it reflects & reinforces a view of women's bodies as ornamental while men's are instrumental. It's time to level the playing field so female athletes don't face the disadvantage that needlessly body-baring clothing can have on athletic performance. No one wins when objectification rules the game. -Lindsay Kite, PhD & Lexie Kite, PhD Authors of More Than a Body @beauty_redefined'.

node.text:
It’s way past time to level the playing field. #morethanabody

➕For more of this, read More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD (or listen on audiobook). Linked in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'A women's handball team is boycotting mandated bikini bottoms for being sexist and inhibiting while the men's teams are fully clothed. This type of uniform double standard is everywhere and it reflects & reinforces a view of women's bodies as ornamental while men's are instrumental. It's time to level the playing field so female athletes don't face the disadvantage that needlessly body-baring clothing can have on athletic performance. No one wins when objectification rules the game. -Lindsay Kite, PhD & Lexie Kite, PhD Authors of More Than a Body @beauty_redefined'.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'International Handball Federation uniform rules: Women must wear a tight-fitting sports bra so the midriff is showing with deep openings at the arms. The bikini bottoms must not be more than 10 centimeters long Men must wear sleeveless tank tops and baggy shorts 10 centimeters above the kneecap. @beauty_redefined'.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'There's nothing wrong with enjoying or feeling great in the standard volleyball, gymnastics, or handball uniform worn by female athletes today. You'll never find us shaming or judging the people who agree to wear or love to wear those uniforms (or anything else, to be honest). Our problem with the uniforms is: 1) the striking disparity between male/female uniforms, which reflects the objectifying idea that women's bodies are primarily ornaments to be looked at; 2) the hindering effect that unnecessarily body-baring clothing has on body image and athletic performance (i.e., self-objectification). @beauty_redefined'.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'In our objectifying culture, girls and women learn to evaluate and control their bodies in terms of their sexual desirability more than anything else. Girls and women are picturing what they look like to others while they are living instead of just living (it's called self-objectification). Serious mental capacity is lost in the process of focusing on your appearance when you should be focusing on anything else. A bright spark in this dim world of body fixation is participating in sports, but not when those sports require sexist, unnecessarily body-bearing dress codes. @beauty_redefined'.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If you are prone to feeling shame and preoccupation with your body, those bikini bottoms and spandex volleyball shorts with little-to-no inseam will likely prevent you from being able to take your mind off the appearance of your body to fully experience the positive effects of the sport. Interesting research backs this up: Prichard and Tiggemann (2005) found that women in fitness centers who wore tight and fitted exercise clothing placed greateremphasis on their appearance attributes and engaged in more habitual body monitoring than women who wore looser clothing (T-shirts and sweatpants). @beauty_redefined'.
Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says '-We believe a less body-baring uniform would promote a higher level of performance among female athletes, especially considering the high percentage who likely struggle with body anxiety on or off the court. -We believe a less body-baring uniform would put female and male athletes on a more equal playing field (or court), because the same sport shouldn't require significantly different uniforms. -We believe a less body bearing uniform would encourage more girls and women to play sports like volleyball, handball, and gymnastics, considering many might count themselves out specifically because of the uniforms. @beauty_redefined'.
Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhDs on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'When we work to understand our bodies as instruments to be used for our benefit rather than ornaments to be admired by others, we start to question the norms and habits that serve only ornamental purposes. We would love to see girls' and women's athletic uniforms align with men's in helping their bodies serve an instrumental role and not an ornamental one. It's time to level the playing field. -Lindsay Kite, PhD & Lexie Kite, PhD Authors of More Than a Body @beauty_redefined'.

node.text:
What surprised us the most in our doctoral body image research? Lindsay shares the interesting difference between women who feel good about their bodies because they look good vs. those who hated their bodies because they look "bad" -- and what they all had in common regardless of how they looked. Watch or listen til the end for the good stuff! 
👙Hint: being thin, having a perfect "bikini body," looking young while aging, and meeting every other female beauty ideal isn't the cure-all confidence solution you might think it is. 🙏🏼Thankfully, we found MUCH more effective, achievable and sustainable answers for your body image woes!
📖Find our book, More Than a Body, by Lindsay and Lexie Kite, PhD, everywhere books are sold (hardcover, ebook, audio!) or at your library -- shopping links in our bio!

node.text:
Our game-changing TEDx talk took place 4 years ago, and it still holds up! (Phew). Linds nails the core of our work at Beauty Redefined and our debut book, More Than a Body, in these few minutes. 
✖️As she says here and we fully dive into in our book, "Girls and women aren't only suffering because of the unattainable ways beauty is being defined, they're suffering because THEY ARE BEING DEFINED BY BEAUTY. They are bodies first and people second. So rather than working to make sure more women's bodies are viewed as valuable, we are focused on making sure women are valued as more than bodies to view."🔥💥🙌🏽
✖️The truth is: Feeling like other people think you look good is fleeting, and it's causing you to put your power in the hands of onlookers. It's shoving you onto an exhausting roller coaster of ups and downs based on validation from others and good lighting and bad hair days and on and on. You are more than a body. You are not required to please the eyes of those who see you. You have work to do, and we need you out here! We need YOU -- not a pretty vision of you -- all of you.
➕If you feel the power of her words here, you’ll dig our book, “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. Complete with our personal stories of growing up as identical twins that were constantly compared (including 13-yr-old journal entries), finding purpose in our lifetimes of body shame when we went to college and realized we could help people heal from their shame, and putting ALL our research and answers to help people rise with body image resilience into our book is the best and hardest thing we’ve ever done. Like harder than writing doctoral dissertations, giving birth, and trying not to laugh when people asked us growing up, “How do you know if you are Lexie or Lindsay when you wake up in the morning?”😂 The full TEDx talk is linked in our bio, or just search Lindsay Kite TEDx on YouTube! 📚 Get “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD (available in our OWN twin voices as an audiobook, too!) wherever books are sold (linked in bio & morethanabody.org). #morethanabody #seemorebemore

node.text:
☝🏽This. This mindset shift is crucial to building your body image resilience. This stuff is WORK. It’s easy to feel like you are getting a good body image boost from all of the content we and our colleagues post on social media and our podcast interviews and all that, but the best compliment we keep getting is that people who have followed our work for years are blown away by our book. GAH. WE LOVE TO SEE IT! 
➕We just saw this beautiful review from @bookgirlgen that sums up what we want for everyone to feel when they read our book, “More Than a Body:”
“Sometimes a book comes along that lifts a veil off your eyes and you forever see yourself and the world differently. I'm not talking about just useful, interesting information, but knowledge and understanding that fundamentally changes you to your core. More Than a Body is that for me and I hope for generations to come.”
➕This book is everything we can’t write in tiny captions and square images. It walks you through a therapeutic path from that little “you” as a carefree child to you returning home to yourself after years of carrying your body around like an embarrassing burden. Have you read the final chapter, The Reunion? It’s our favorite and we are not ashamed to admit we still get choked up re-reading that reunion scene.🥲
➕The ideas in our book are new. You haven’t read it before. Not even from all of our free content. It’s personal, it’s candid, it’s theory and practice. It’s for you. We’re so excited for you to read it and live with a priority on how YOU experience the world, not how the world experiences you! 
More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD is available in hardcover📚, audiobook🎧, and Kindle📱 anywhere books are sold! Linked in bio and at morethanabody.org. #morethanabody

node.text:
Ever wonder why so many dress codes spend all the time on what the girls are wearing? Why people who are raised in cultures w/ strict female dress codes are more 👀 preoccupied by female bodies than those who aren’t? Ever question why so many swimming dress codes enforce that girls’ stomachs must be covered but not boys’? Or why boys’ mid-thigh shorts are fine but girls’ need to be called out & measured? 
✖️Are girls’ shoulders, thighs, or midriffs inherently sexy? Of course not. But in cultures that enforce dress rules that focus on specific parts, those parts suddenly become sexually charged as both enticing & shameful. We inadvertently teach heterosexual boys that girls' bodies are made up of tempting and threatening parts. We start judging girls that dare to bare their shoulders, legs or belly. We notice when certain parts are visible & attribute meaning to it (she covers that so she’s a “good girl” & vice versa). We get out rulers to measure their skin. This double standard exists because we’ve been taught to see women as objects to be looked at, judged, used, & discarded. Where men are clearly seen as more than bodies, women are not afforded that humanity. 
✖️Let's do the heterosexual boys & men of the world a solid and STOP perpetuating the myth that they are subject to uncontrollable thoughts and actions. This normalizes and justifies a culture where rape & violence is somehow the victim's fault, where we ask what she was wearing when that has no bearing on the crime. 
👊🏽HERE'S THE TRUTH: We ALL face regular opportunities for sexual arousal & distraction. Trying to control girls' clothing doesn't prevent boys from sexual thoughts or protect girls from boys' actions. Solve the ACTUAL problem by teaching all people that girls are more than bodies and more than sexy threats to onlookers. Boys are more than bodies, too. More than uncontrollable desires & instincts. Give people their humanity back by holding them accountable for their own behavior. 
➕Want more on this AND our solutions? It’s all in our debut book “More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD (in hardcover, audiobook, and Kindle) at the link in bio & morethanabody.org! #morethanabody

node.text:
Every time you see a comment from someone concern-trolling another person’s "health" because they embrace their body as it is or looks different than the world thinks they should, send them over here to our rant (swipe for it all), and of course encourage them to check out our verrrrry comprehensive take on all this, our debut book, More Than a Body! We've got you covered.👊🏽
⚠️And PLEASE oh PLEASE keep in mind good health is not achievable or accessible to everyone. Before you judge yourself or anyone else for their supposed health, understand that the most powerful determinants of health are often OUTSIDE of our control. Where you grew up, what community resources you had access to, your family’s wealth, and other systemic factors affect a person’s health outcomes in ways that can’t be fixed with lifestyle changes, no matter how easy you think it should be. END RANT😅
➕For more, pick up our debut book, More Than a Body, by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD. 🎧We narrated the audiobook, too, so you can hear us read to you if you’d prefer that over the hardcover or Kindle! You can guess which one of us and our identical twin voices is narrating each chapter! We honestly couldn’t tell each others’ voices apart some of the time. Links in bio! #morethanabody

node.text:
This stuff takes work. Like WORK WORK. It can’t be boiled down to one viral tweet, a couple days of digging into body neutrality, seeing body positive ad campaigns, and then sinking back into your normal, unquestioned objectifying environment where beauty, thinness and youth are obligations for living a happy, full life. We literally wrote a book on this topic to counteract the super viral idea that the “every body is beautiful” notion fixes your body image.
🔥BEAUTY WON’T SAVE US.🔥Not even expanding the parameters of who GETS to be beautiful. We’re so much more than beauty, more than bodies, more than parts to love and hate and flaunt and fix. 
➕To be honest, when we saw this tweet go viral, our hearts sunk. Yeah, it’s great to see people pick up this idea, but this is exactly what we’ve been teaching for 10+ years online, in thousands of free posts, countless events and interviews, and an online body image resilience course of which we’ve given hundreds of people full scholarships to enroll, and now in a WHOLE BOOK on the subject! 🤣 We developed an accessible, life-giving pathway to Body Image Resilience in our PhD research and want the world to know how possible it is to not only REJECT the objectifying culture we can’t see outside of, but RISE WITH RESILIENCE not just in spite of our objectification, but because of it. Body image resilience is the revolution we all need.
👊🏽So yeah, borrow or buy our book - we want that very much for you and for us - and know that your body image resilience journey has just begun. And it is SO WORTH IT. Links to More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD on 🎧audiobook, 📚hardcover, and 📱Kindle are in bio. #morethanabody

node.text:
In our book, More Than a Body, we argue that men are not just *allowed* to age, but encouraged, celebrated, and upheld as sexy, wise  silver foxes while women are punished, pushed to the sidelines, and shamed into submission around age 40. The multi-billion dollar "anti-aging" industry and the sexist media industry make SURE this is the case. 
➕Some stats from our book: "62 percent of women in the US are over 40. But get this: older men appear as much as 10X more frequently than older women in media. Even when TV and film depictions of relationships feature older men, their girlfriends and wives are most often decades younger (see the roles and sometimes the real lives of Johnny Depp, Leo DiCaprio, all the James Bonds, etc). Men are featured well into their 70s, while women tend to start becoming scarce right around age 40."
➕”That makes the way women are represented especially important. Think of the wise, funny, “sexy” image represented by leading men well into their 50s, 60s, 70s — Harrison Ford, Denzel Washington, Colin Firth, Javier Bardem, Tom Cruise, Liam Neeson, Will Smith, George Clooney. etc. In the music industry, older male artists thrive — just consider who has performed in the Super Bowl halftime show the last 20 years: Paul McCartney, Aerosmith, Bruce Springsteen, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Sting, the Rolling Stones, Lenny Kravitz, the Who.
➕Trying to come up with an equally long, diverse list of female performers over age 50 is more difficult. Thankfully, there are some actors who fit this bill, like Meryl Streep, Julia Roberts, Helen Mirren, Viola Davis, Julianne Moore, and Diane Keaton, though few are paired alongside a younger partner like their male counterparts. Naming female artists at the Super Bowl is much more difficult: Madonna & Jennifer Lopez (sliding in at age 50 at the time) are the ONLY two over 50 who have ever performed.”
➕The first step to reclaiming your body and life is to see what sources are working to disempower you. Now you can’t unsee it. For more, read More Than a Body by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD! 🎯On SALE for $15 at Target & Amazon right now!🚨Linked in bio. #morethanabody

node.text:
Our approach to body image work is different than a lot of “love your body” stuff out there because we are trying to separate peoples’ worth from their appearance completely. Not just expanding who gets to feel beautiful, but taking beauty OFF the pedestal we shouldn’t be required to stand on. Straight from our TEDx talk and our book, “More Than a Body”:
✖️”Girls and women aren’t only suffering because of the unattainable ways beauty is being defined, they’re suffering because they are being *defined by beauty.* They are bodies first and people second. So, rather than working to make sure more women’s bodies are viewed as valuable, we are working to make sure women are valued as more than bodies to view. Our work is founded on the premise that positive body image isn’t believing your body looks good; it is believing your body is good, regardless of how it looks.”
✖️Please know the problem is NOT your body. The problem is believing you are just a body. It’s like our bodies aren’t part of us, but ALL of us. When we fight back by alleviating the shame surrounding certain body types, we’re only fighting a *symptom* of the problem, not the root cause. We’re here to remind you women are MORE than bodies, and it’s time to SEE more and BE more. It’s time to heal our relationships with our bodies so we can show up in a world that is desperate for us to lead, do, be & speak up.👊🏽
➕“More Than a Body” by Lexie & Lindsay Kite, PhD, is available anywhere books are sold (and get it on 🎧audiobook too so you can hear us read it to you ourselves!🙌🏽) Links in bio, and watch our TEDx talk there too. #morethanabody #seemorebemore
